Theoretically, yes, TX power increase should increase throughput, but an increase by a factor of 10? Not likely. Also, there are many factors at play when determining your speed. I'm only talking about the theoretical maximum for the line itself. And yes modulation scheme is one of those factors. Keep in mind that Internet traffic isn't the only thing being carried by the coax lines. TV transmission talked up a lot of the bandwidth for coax lines. Yes, the signals are segregated but in an overall sense, if half of the bandwidth of a coax line is dedicated to tv, then you've already dropped that 3-4 Gbps down to 1.5-2 Gbps. Factor in users on a segment, the aging condition of the majority of the lines in place and you aren't going to get that 1Gbps speed. And exactly how would you """"halve the distance""""? Unless you are looking at moving into a place that is right next to the provider node, your TX distance isn't something that you have control over. And if you are looking at doubling the modulation scheme, you'd better have that TX power problem solved, otherwise, you aren't going to get your improved signal to the home at the power levels needed to provide the increased speed. At any rate, the solutions you stated might work but it's going to take a hell of a lot more than just replacing a modem to make it work. To many times we are told of a """"breakthrough"""" without realizing that this """"breakthrough """" occurred in a lab, under optimal conditions and doesn't have any relation to the real world and how these systems operate in it.

Regarding the public education issue, the academic elite seem to be disconnected from the people on the ground. With job losses, immigration and unemployment, people are displaced and become transient. Without stability, Kids who are transient don't have an easy time studying, or learning, because they move so often. They can't concentrate, it's not their fault...society doesn't see them, but teachers do. By the time they get to college age, they don't have all the fundamentals, even though they have desire. The 4 year public college, like the community colleges are subjected to state government funding and control. Once FOR PROFIT colleges were allowed to tap into federal student loan money, all college costs spiraled everywhere. Congress holds the purse strings and regulations on who gets our tax money. For profit education, made some rich while taking advantage of veterans, and seniors too.
